title: Is there any reason to choose Ancient Coin over Frost Queen's Claim?
body:
The original purpose of the support item trio was to complement a champion's kit and playstyle. Targon giving sustain and health for melee supports, Frost giving damage for damage supports, and Coin giving health for passive supports. With the new quest system, Targon and Frost has seen an upgrade however the Coin lineup got reworked and it's quest reward is almost worthless when compared with Targon and Frost. 

Instead of Coin giving health, it gives a random chance of gold or mana that drops from minions like Thresh's soul mechanic and like Thresh, you have to approach them to receive them. Who is supposed to benefit from this item now? Why would a passive support choose this item now over Frost when Frost gives better stats and rewards all around? 

The quest reward for Coin, Elixir of Skill, while neat in concept, its poor in execution. Could we perhaps get another quest reward or maybe buff Elixir to where it increases your ult rank by 1 if not already maxed out? And can we please change the passive of Talisman of Ascension's "Point Runner"? Im not saying I dont like Point Runner at all it just that there are multiple items I build that also has Point Runner which makes them a waste of value. Maybe replace the passive to where it increases movement speed by 5%, that increases to 10% when out of combat? 

I dont know, what do you guys think?

Sooo, I don't really disagree with you, but there are a few technical mistakes in what you say, so I'm gonna address that first.

> With the new quest system, Targon and Frost has seen an upgrade however the Coin lineup got reworked and it's quest reward is almost worthless

1. Coin getting reworked and the quest system being added are two different and unrelated things. You could get the new Coin dropping loot from minions without a Quest system at all.
2. +1 skill point is a very, very under-rated reward. It doesn't **feel** impactful, and yet it **is**. The main problem is that it's useless post-level 17, whereas the other rewards are still very useful, but games rarely go long enough for supports to reach level 18. So mostly, it's a problem on paper, but not in reality.

> Instead of Coin giving health, it gives a random chance of gold or mana that drops from minions [...] Who is supposed to benefit from this item now? Why would a passive support choose this item now over Frost when Frost gives better stats and rewards all around?

All support items give roughly the same amount of Gold, so what you really have to consider is actually the mana from Coin versus the damage from Spellthief. Passive supports who don't aim to kill their opponents in lane don't care about the damage and prefer the mana to use more spells for sustain/defensive CC/etc.

___

Overall, I do agree that Ancien Coin feels bad, but the item is actually better than it feels, you can't really straight buff it.

It doesnt feel impactful because it isnt. By the time you get your Skill Elixer, you most likely already maxed out your main skill that has the most impact like Soraka's heal and Janna's shield. Its not like you're actually getting a level up where you get additional stats so ranking Soraka's Q from 1 to 2 is not going to make a big difference.

Passive supports who don't aim to kill their opponents in lane don't care about the damage and prefer the mana to use more spells for sustain/defensive CC/etc.
> 

Frost Queen gives mana regen. Although not as much as Coin's however there is minimal mana management involved with Meditation mastery making the two support items mana regen difference not that big.

They are unrelated, because you could remove the Quest system, and still keep the dropping coins system to get gold. They were two changes that tried to achieve the same goal, but they still are two **independent** changes. Relic Shield and Spellthief received a Quest too, without changing how they collect gold. How Coin collects gold and the Quest it received are two independent things.

And +1 Skillpoint is impactful, yes. One rank up in Soraka's Q is +40 damage. Compare that to the shield you get from the Relic Shield line, and you don't need a lot of Q hitting to get a bigger benefit. But when you hit a Q, you don't realize, you don't see that damage coming from the Elixir, you just see your Q hitting. So you don't *feel* the impact, but it's still there.

And if you don't have mana regen problem with Spellthief, yes, do take Spellthief instead of Ancient Coin. But if you are regularly OOM, keep in mind you have that other option. You asked who is supposed to use Ancient Coin, I answered. Maybe it's not for you, but it has its uses.

4. You get CDR at level 1
5. You can get some nice armor and speedboost near turret.

Coin's whole shritck is to be a fallback option when you can't make the most of either Relic shield or SpellThief in your given matchup.

I had an experience where a Sorakka support I was playing with had to walk up to pick up her coins against the opposing Draven, after the first back, he was quarter shoting her whenever she tried to pick up a coin and eventually, to prevent herself from dieing, she had to stop picking up the coins altogether. 

However, the argument can be made that which support items you buy should be matchup based (don't take coin into Draven, but maybe against some other ADC, it'd be less punishing) But even with that in mind, it seems that Coin is not worth the health cost you suffer for picking up the drops. I think this problem would be solved with some minor buffs to range of pickup and reword for getting them.

A major problem is that the other two items depend on your ability to do an action (poke or execute minions) while the coins are totally up to someone else (the adc) to provide a safe lane for you to pick them up.  As someone who plays a fair amount of support, picking up the coins is actually really easy... if your adc is better than the enemy adc and can help zone.  But again, the type of support who would take this item isnt known for zone pressure, so again its up to the adc to make or break the item for you.

You can't seriously believe that 60% movement speed (40% reliably on everyone every 60 seconds, 20% if near fallen) <  50% movement speed for one second (you need one entire minute after the first stack for it to be 3 seconds, with a 1.25 second cd between each proc.)

If we add the movement speed decrease, the active itself counters the coin active for only two people.

The reason is because not every support can execute minions (not melee) or can't reliably proc tribute (see {{champion:497}} and {{champion:16}} for prime examples). It lets you be more safe regardless (you don't need to step on the coins. You can stand a minion or two away from it and pick it up. They also last for a while), and doesn't require as much mana to use (important on Janna, who takes a TON of mana to cast Q or W).

It's just Riot's latest failure in trying to make supports "interesting" to encourage more people to play the role. Maybe if they were actually a threat during the early lane phase, more people would play them. Players tend to like killing other players, which explains why mages are finding their way into the support role again.

The problem with 3 gold items is that supports are only made of two broad classes, mages and tanks, so there should only be two gold items because of that (relic for tanks, and the stronger between coin or spell thief for mages).
IMO, it's mostly dependent on {{item:3069}} being better than {{item:3092}} on certain supports; it just sucks until you get there
